1.text: Lo, mine eye hath seen all [this], mine ear hath heard and understood it.

2.text: What ye know, I know also: I am not inferior to you.

3.text: But I will speak to the Almighty, and will find pleasure in reasoning with God;

4.text: For ye indeed are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.

5.text: Oh that ye would be altogether silent! and it would be your wisdom.

6.text: Hear now my defence, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.

7.text: Will ye speak unrighteously for God? and for him speak deceit?

8.text: Will ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?

9.text: Will it be well if he should search you out? or as one mocketh at a man, will ye mock at him?

10.text: He will certainly reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.

11.text: Shall not his excellency terrify you? and his dread fall upon you?

12.text: Your memorable sayings are proverbs of ashes, your bulwarks are bulwarks of mire.

13.text: Hold your peace from me, and I will speak, and let come on me what [will]!

14.text: Wherefore should I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in my hand?

15.text: Behold, if he slay me, yet would I trust in him; but I will defend mine own ways before him.

16.text: This also shall be my salvation, that a profane man shall not come before his face.

17.text: Hear attentively my speech and my declaration with your ears.

18.text: Behold now, I have ordered the cause; I know that I shall be justified.

19.text: Who is he that contendeth with me? For if I were silent now, I should expire.

20.text: Only do not two things unto me; then will I not hide myself from thee.

21.text: Withdraw thy hand far from me; and let not thy terror make me afraid:

22.text: Then call, and I will answer; or I will speak, and answer thou me.

23.text: How many are mine iniquities and sins? Make me to know my transgression and my sin.

24.text: Wherefore dost thou hide thy face, and countest me for thine enemy?

25.text: Wilt thou terrify a driven leaf? and wilt thou pursue dry stubble?

26.text: For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth;

27.text: And thou puttest my feet in the stocks, and markest all my paths; thou settest a bound about the soles of my feet;â€”

28.text: One who, as a rotten thing consumeth, as a garment that the moth eateth.
